text: And God said unto Abraham, As for Sarai thy wife, thou shalt not call her name Sarai, but Sarah shall her name be.
text_kjv: And God said unto Abraham, As for Sarai thy wife, thou shalt not call her name Sarai, but Sarah shall her name be.
text_niv: God also said to Abraham, “As for Sarai your wife, you are no longer to call her Sarai; her name will be Sarah.
text_esv: And God said to Abraham, “As for Sarai your wife, you shall not call her name Sarai, but Sarah  shall be her name.
text_nlt: Then God said to Abraham, “Regarding Sarai, your wife — her name will no longer be Sarai. From now on her name will be Sarah.
text_msg: God continued speaking to Abraham, "And Sarai your wife: Don't call her Sarai any longer; call her Sarah.
text_nasb: Then God said to Abraham, 'As for Sarai your wife, you shall not call her name Sarai, but Sarah [shall be] her name.
context: Genesis 17 marks a pivotal moment in the covenant relationship between God and Abraham. Abraham, at 99 years old, receives a renewed confirmation of God's promise of countless descendants and the land of Canaan. Names held significant meaning in the ancient Near East; they weren't mere labels but reflected a person's character, destiny, or role. A change in name often signified a change in status or a new beginning, particularly in the context of a divine encounter. Sarai's name, likely meaning 'my princess' (implying a limited or personal dominion), was common among women of status in that era. The patriarchal structure of society heavily influenced family dynamics, with a strong emphasis on lineage and the importance of producing heirs to carry on the family name and inheritance. The blessing of numerous descendants was a highly valued societal ideal, and infertility was often viewed as a curse or divine disfavor. Abraham and Sarai had waited decades for a child, and their advanced age further complicated the situation. This context underscores the magnitude of God's promise of a son through Sarai, emphasizing both the divine power and the deeply personal connection within the covenant. Furthermore, the use of divine names El and El Shaddai throughout this chapter highlights God's sovereignty and ability to fulfill even seemingly impossible promises. Circumcision was introduced as a sign of this covenant, a physical representation of their commitment to God's promise. This act would set Abraham and his descendants apart as God's chosen people.
meaning: The change of Sarai's name to Sarah is not merely a cosmetic alteration; it represents a profound shift in her status and destiny. The new name, Sarah, likely means 'princess of a multitude' or 'noble woman,' signifying a universal blessing and dominion far beyond her previous role as 'my princess.' This renaming is intrinsically linked to God's promise to make her the mother of nations, a role far greater than she could have imagined. The theological significance lies in God's active intervention in their lives, rewriting their story and fulfilling promises that seemed humanly impossible. It demonstrates God's power to transform and elevate, taking individuals from a place of limitation and doubt to a position of blessing and influence. The promise of offspring through Sarah, despite her age and previous infertility, highlights the theme of divine grace and the overcoming of human limitations by God's power. The naming also signifies a new covenantal identity. Sarah becomes a symbolic mother of the covenant people, a figure whose lineage extends to kings and nations. This underscores the importance of faith and obedience in God's plan, as both Abraham and Sarah were called to trust in God's word despite the seeming impossibility of the situation. Through this act, God establishes a lineage of blessing that will eventually extend to all nations (Galatians 3:8-9), highlighting the universal scope of God's redemptive plan.
application: Genesis 17:15 offers profound lessons for modern believers. Firstly, it reminds us that God can transform our identities and purposes. Just as Sarai's name was changed to reflect her new destiny, God can redefine our lives, moving us from a place of limitation to one of purpose and fulfillment. We may feel stuck in old patterns, defined by past failures, or confined by present circumstances. However, God can break through these limitations and reveal a new, more glorious future for us. Secondly, this verse calls us to trust in God's promises, even when they seem impossible. Sarah's advanced age and history of infertility made the promise of motherhood seem ludicrous. Yet, she (eventually) believed God, and her faith was counted to her as righteousness. We, too, face seemingly insurmountable challenges, dreams that seem unattainable, and situations that defy logic. This passage encourages us to cling to God's word, to trust in His power, and to believe that He is able to do exceedingly abundantly above all that we ask or think. Thirdly, Sarah's story highlights the importance of embracing our role in God's plan. She wasn't merely a passive recipient of God's blessing; she was an active participant in fulfilling His covenant. Similarly, we are called to embrace our unique roles in God's kingdom, to use our gifts and talents to serve others, and to contribute to the advancement of His purposes on earth. Finally, this passage emphasizes the importance of legacy. Sarah became the mother of nations, leaving a lasting impact on the world. We, too, can leave a legacy of faith, hope, and love, impacting generations to come through our actions, words, and relationships. We can strive to live lives that honor God and inspire others to follow Him.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the powerful reminder in Sarah's story that you are a God of transformation and promise. We confess that we often limit you with our doubts and fears, failing to believe in the seemingly impossible. Forgive us for our lack of faith. Lord, we ask that you would reveal the areas in our lives where you desire to bring change and renewal. Give us the courage to embrace a new identity in you, to step into the destiny you have planned for us. Help us to trust in your promises, even when they seem beyond our reach. Empower us to be active participants in your kingdom, using our gifts and talents to serve you and others. May our lives leave a lasting legacy of faith, hope, and love, impacting generations to come. We commit ourselves to you and ask for your guidance and strength in all things. In Jesus' name, amen.

faqs.answer: The name change occurred at this specific point because it signified the formal establishment and confirmation of the covenant promise of a son and numerous descendants. It was a tangible symbol of God's commitment and Sarah's new role in fulfilling that promise.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Why was Sarai's name changed at this specific time?

faqs.answer: No, Abraham's name was also changed (from Abram to Abraham) in the same chapter. Furthermore, later in Genesis, Jacob's name is changed to Israel (Genesis 32:28), also signifying a new identity and destiny.
faqs.question: Q2: Is Sarah's name change the only name change mentioned in Genesis?

faqs.answer: This verse reveals God's character as a covenant-keeping God who is faithful to His promises, even when circumstances seem impossible. It highlights His power to transform lives and fulfill His purposes through unlikely individuals.
faqs.question: Q3: What does this verse teach us about God's character?

faqs.answer: The passage doesn't explicitly state Abraham's emotional reaction, but it's implied that he accepted God's decree. He obeyed God's command regarding circumcision immediately after, indicating his faith and obedience.
faqs.question: Q4: How did Abraham react to the name change?

faqs.answer: Yes, Sarah remains a significant figure as the matriarch of the Jewish people and a symbol of faith and motherhood. Her story inspires believers to trust in God's promises and embrace their role in His plan, regardless of age or circumstance.
